title: 'Mad at the World: A Life of John Steinbeck' Review: The Poison Cup of Gold
summary: His drive to create was unstoppable-and so was his need for solitude.. In 1937, John Steinbeck began to be disturbed by unannounced visitors at the small cottage north of Monterey that he shared with his wife Carol. Steinbeck had just published "Of Mice and Men," which he wrote at the kitchen table beside an open wood stove during the daylight hours, because the kerosene lamp gave him eyestrain. They had no telephone; when the stage play Steinbeck adapted with George S. Kaufman premiered on Broadway, he and Carol had to drive five miles to a neighbor's house to hear how it was received. The sudden appearance of fans at his front door upended their spartan, happily impoverished life. Steinbeck built walls around the property and removed the sign with his name at the entrance. Zeppo Marx tried to reach him and Steinbeck refused to get back in touch. But he was sufficiently awed when Charlie Chaplin showed up one day in a stretch limo. They got along well, though Chaplin thought it strange that the Steinbecks didn't have maids to do the cleaning.

title: Covid-19 and President Trump: What Scientists Know About Effects on the Body, Treatments
summary: Doctors have learned more about how the virus impacts the body, effective treatments and how to prevent its spread. President Trump and first lady Melania Trump have tested positive for Covid-19. Here's the latest that we know about the virus, its spread and treatment.

title: How to Avoid Paying the Cruelest Tax: Inflation
summary: Investors worried that record budget deficits and massive Fed bond buying will stoke a big rise in inflation have places to hide aside from hoarding gold coins-some of them surprising. With their portfolios gyrating and an election looming, investors are spending more time than usual pondering what their taxes will look like in the future. But they haven't given much thought lately to "the cruelest tax"-inflation. Maybe they should.

title: 'Lords of the Fly' Review: Long Live the Silver King!
summary: In pursuit of the monarch of the fly-rod fishing world, the mighty Atlantic tarpon.. What Susan Orlean accomplished for the strange, hermetic world of orchid hunting in her 1998 classic "The Orchid Thief," Monte Burke does for another strange, hermetic world in his wonderful "Lords of the Fly: Madness, Obsession, and the Hunt for the World-Record Tarpon."

title: An Essential Sport: Two Books on Baseball
summary: How it became part of America, and how statistics became part of the fun.. Baseball, like the rest of us, has had a rough 2020.

title: 'Last Mission to Tokyo' Review: Torture on Trial
summary: The 'Doolittle Raid' on Japan had a little known final act-in the courtroom.. 'How do you tell a man that he will be killed tomorrow?" With that question Michel Paradis begins his story of the Doolittle Raid on Tokyo during World War II and of its immediate aftermath, when the Japanese executed three airmen for the raid and subjected five others to prolonged suffering. A postwar trial was supposed to punish the tormenters-and that story, too, is part of Mr. Paradis's superb "Last Mission to Tokyo."

title: 'The WEIRDest People in the World' Review: Marriage Story
summary: An evolutionary biologist argues that a change in how we coupled made the modern West radically different.. We may think that the culture of a society or civilization grows out of a variety of forces-social, political, historical, even biological. But what if culture is itself a potent force, one that, in part, shapes the others? "Culture," Joseph Henrich writes, "can and does alter our brains, hormones, and anatomy, along with our perceptions, motivations, personalities, [and] emotions." He assumes, for instance, a high degree of literacy in his readers and thus confidently describes certain features of their brains: e.g., slight abnormalities in the left ventral occipito-temporal region, part of a structure that favors verbal memory and analytic processing skills. Compared with most people around the world and throughout human history, he notes, these attributes are exceedingly rare.

title: Political Books: After the Culture War
summary: To weather a rising tide of intolerance, these writers want American Christians to prepare themselves for a new kind of struggle.. The American left dominates nearly every major institution in the country, and yet Donald Trump's presidency continues to inspire progressives with a revanchist zeal. Tacit and sometimes explicit approval of violent protests; embrace of an "anti-racist" agenda that defines the United States as a brutal and twisted regime; policies aimed at the comprehensive reorganization of the private sector; Maoist denunciations of well-meaning people for the slightest offenses against constantly changing norms-all this was happening at lower levels of intensity before Mr. Trump arrived on the scene and will likely not dissipate when he departs.

title: Chance of a Lifetime
summary: Two books ask: What are the chances that mere physical matter would begin to organize itself into life?. When you're feeling small and insecure, just remember how unlikely is your birth. That's the advice from a song in "Monty Python's The Meaning of Life," and it's the premise of "A Series of Fortunate Events," Sean B. Carroll's entertaining examination of the chain of accidents that led from dinosaur extinction to our existence today. Going even further back, we could wonder how life itself ever came into being, and Jeremy England does so in "Every Life Is on Fire."

title: 'Phallacy: Life Lessons From the Animal Penis' Review: Genitalia Tales
summary: Science has diligently studied the male organ. The female? Not so much.. Biologically speaking, you'd expect a penis to be pretty simple, says science writer Emily Willingham. "There's no obvious reason to think," she writes in "Phallacy: Life Lessons From the Animal Penis," "that animals need anything more complicated than a tube that allows passage of semen and enters a partner. Yet yowie zowie, do they do so much more than that."

title: 'Ballet in the Cold War' Review: Diplomacy in Dance
summary: Toe-shoe to toe-shoe competition sent ballet companies into battle for their respective nations.. Highest-quality artistry in the service of competing empires: that is the subject of Anne Searcy's "Ballet in the Cold War," a new study of four major cultural-exchange ballet tours at the height of the Cold War. Moscow's Bolshoi Ballet made its U.S. debut in 1959 and returned in 1962; American Ballet Theatre's tour of the Soviet Union in 1960 was followed by New York City Ballet's Russian debut two years later. Although these tours have already been covered in a number of excellent books, Ms. Searcy, an assistant professor at the University of Washington's School of Music, stakes her claim with extensive research in Russian and American archives and her manifest enthusiasm for the subject.

title: Trump's Positive Covid Test
summary: His infection isn't karma, and he can set an example of optimism as he recovers.. America, or at least the non- Twitter part of it, is wishing President Trump and his wife Melania a speedy recovery after their positive tests for Covid-19. The good news is that, even in the worst medical case, the United States has the constitutional measures in place to assure continuity of governance. This may even be an instructive moment for the American people.

title: A Huawei Turning Point
summary: Germany could soon effectively ban the firm from its 5G network.. The Trump Administration has had some success convincing allies to exclude Huawei from their 5G networks, but Germany has been the most significant holdout. It's good news then that Berlin soon will address the security risk posed by the Chinese telecom giant.

title: More Jobs Momentum
summary: The labor market continues to recover despite state closures.. The private U.S. economy added 877,000 new jobs in September, but you'd think from the coverage that this was bad news. While the pace of hiring has slowed since the summer, the economy and labor market still have plenty of growth momentum.

title: 'Kindred' Review: Our Neanderthal Cousins
summary: Getting to know our misunderstood relatives and the world that died with them.. In "The Library of Babel" (1941), the author Jorge Luis Borges imagined an infinite library of books. Each was unique, and despite containing great swaths of irrelevancies, the library represented all possibility, including accounts of the past, present and future. One might similarly imagine another kind of infinite library, comprising not books but the genomes of all possible types of humans. While just one encodes our own species, Homo sapiens, vast numbers would encode different human species that have never existed; others would address precursors such as Homo erectus and Homo habilis.

title: A Supreme Covid Stunt
summary: Democrats try the virus as a new excuse to block Amy Coney Barrett.. When court-packing threats didn't deter Senate Republicans from moving forward with Amy ConeyBarrett's Supreme Court nomination, Democrats seemed to be out of options. But now they sense an opportunity in the Covid-19 diagnoses among Republican officials. Could that be a pretext for drawing out the process past the election-and then sinking Judge Barrett?

title: 'The Perfect Fascist' Review: Mussolini's Man
summary: Corrupt, brutal and utterly loyal: dictatorial rule in Italy depended on the 'gerarchi.'. When Mussolini assumed power in 1922, he surrounded himself with the men who had supported him in his struggles. Known as gerarchi, or hierarchs, they were for the most part veterans of World War I: ruthless, ambitious, greedy and deeply rivalrous among themselves. What they shared was their utter, often craven, dependence on Mussolini, who promoted, favored and sacked them at will. If they annoyed or threatened him, he dispatched them to positions of small power in far-flung lands. Some have come down in history: Italo Balbo for his aviation exploits, Roberto Farinacci for his venality and crassness, Achille Starace for the absurd rituals he imposed on Italy.

title: Trump Can Champion Coronavirus Awareness
summary: He can help himself and the country by turning his diagnosis into a call for following virus protocol.. Now that President Trump has tested positive for Covid-19, he has a unique opportunity to become a poster boy for awareness of the disease. He can transform himself into a strong advocate for individual responsibility to combat the pandemic: urging Americans to follow all the standard recommended protocols, from frequent hand-washing to wearing a mask and social distancing. Doing so would not only be a smart political move but also a monumental service to the nation, clinically and economically.

title: Uber Adapts to Covid and 'Laborism'
summary: Its food-delivery business is booming, but lawmakers threaten its model with restraints on independent contractors. Are self-driving cars the answer?. Uber's CEO is a political refugee. Dara Khosrowshahi, 51, immigrated to the U.S. as a boy after the Iranian revolution in 1979 when the family's pharmaceutical and consumer-products conglomerate was nationalized by the new regime.

title: New York Politicians Decide to Keep a Brooklyn Neighborhood Poor
summary: A proposed waterfront redevelopment would have created thousands of jobs and cost the city nothing.. New York

title: New Stat Augurs Well for Covid Recovery
summary: Gross output measures business confidence better than GDP. It's fallen less than in past recessions.. Wednesday was a big day for anyone with an eye on the economy. For the first time, the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) released the "top line" gross output, or GO, at the same time as it published the "bottom line" gross domestic product. And the GO data brought a welcome surprise: It shows the economy is much more resilient than it looked.

title: A Winding Constitutional Path From Trump to Pence to Pompeo
summary: The president is sick, so here's a review of the laws governing succession.. What if President Trump becomes seriously ill and unable to do his job? Under the 25th Amendment, the president can report to Congress that "he is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office." Vice President Mike Pence would become acting president until Mr. Trump sends a second written declaration that he can perform his duties again.

title: What Happened to Breonna Taylor? What We Know About the Case and Her Death
summary: Grand jury didn't hand down indictments for two other police officers who were involved in shooting. A grand jury indicted a former Louisville, Ky., police officer on criminal charges for his actions on the night Breonna Taylor, a 26-year-old Black woman, was fatally shot by police.

title: Bond Yields Rise in Volatile Trading
summary: Treasury move follows initial decline in yields following President Trump's coronavirus disclosure. U.S. government-bond yields whipsawed before settling higher Friday, swung by the president's positive Covid-19 test, a lackluster jobs report and hopes for further stimulus from lawmakers.

title: New U.S. Coronavirus Cases Above 40,000
summary: Total confirmed infections in U.S. rise to nearly 7.28 million, while the deaths top 208,000. New coronavirus cases in the U.S. topped 40,000 for the third day in a row, as President Trumptested positive for Covid-19 and was later admitted to Walter Reed Medical Center for treatment.

title: Bankrupt Fracker Sable Permian to Sell to Bank Lenders
summary: Lenders led by JPMorgan agree to trade their debt claims for ownership of the West Texas fracker. Bankrupt shale fracker Sable Permian Resources LLC has agreed to sell itself to bank lenders, all but wiping out more than $700 million of debt held by secured bondholders.

title: Top Wall Street Derivatives Cop to Step Down
summary: CFTC's James McDonald is set to depart a week after agency imposed record-setting fine on JPMorgan. WASHINGTON-The chief enforcement watchdog of U.S. derivatives markets is stepping down as his agency wraps up some of its largest investigations.

title: Former Senate Leaders, Cabinet Secretaries Aim to Shore Up Trust in Vote
summary: Group will fund an ad campaign focused on swing states that asks voters to be patient as ballots are tallied; Alaska GOP senator's race becomes competitive. A BIPARTISAN GROUP OF FORMER CONGRESSIONAL LEADERS and cabinet secretaries will fund an ad campaign defending the legitimacy of U.S. elections and asking voters to be patient as ballots are tallied this fall. The group, led by former Senate Majority Leaders Tom Daschle, a Democrat, and Bill Frist, a Republican, will spend $4 million on their campaign, focused on battleground states including Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. The group's several dozen members also include former Democratic House Majority Leader Dick Gephardt and Bush Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff.

title: The Millionaire Who Gave Moderna a Shot
summary: Legions of investors piled into Moderna Inc. this year, drawn by its position as a front-runner in the global hunt for a coronavirus vaccine. Hedge-fund manager Patrick Degorce has been a believer for nearly a decade.. The first time hedge-fund manager Patrick Degorce met with biotech company Moderna Inc., it was a hail-Mary effort to find a cure for his wife.

title: Rochester, N.Y., Mayor Accused of Campaign-Finance Fraud
summary: Warren, who faces two felony charges, has been working to overhaul the city's police department after the death of Daniel Prude. The mayor of Rochester, N.Y., was charged with two felonies on Friday over allegations of campaign-finance fraud, dealing another blow to an administration that has been rocked by the police-involved asphyxiation death of Daniel Prude.

title: Pandemic Home Buyers Drive Aspen's New Gold Rush
summary: Sales and prices jump as the Colorado town attracts urbanites from both coasts and Texas; some local businesses smell opportunity. ASPEN, Colo.-Prices have gotten so high here that a $1.8 million home late last year was included in an affordable-housing lottery by the Aspen Pitkin County Housing Authority.

title: Breonna Taylor Grand Jury Recordings: Officers Testified They Knocked Before Entering
summary: Kentucky prosecutor's opening statements and recommendations not included in audio files. The Kentucky attorney general's office released recordings of the grand jury proceedings in the Breonna Taylor case Friday, including officers' testimony that they repeatedly knocked and announced themselves before entering her apartment.

title: White House Objects to FDA's Proposed Vaccine Standards
summary: Though Trump administration hasn't approved proposed guidelines, U.S. health officials still expected to follow them in weighing whether to permit vaccine's use. Senior White House officials have raised objections to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration's proposed standards for deciding whether a Covid-19 vaccine should be given widely and don't appear likely to sign off on the agency's guidelines, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Tesla Quarterly Deliveries Hit Record as Car Maker's Recovery Speeds Up
summary: Car production bounced back after its U.S. factory was partly shut down in the spring. Tesla Inc. vehicle deliveries hit a new record in the most recent quarter, accelerating the Silicon Valley car maker's recovery after sales slowed during the height of the pandemic.

title: Stocks Drop After Trump Test
summary: Tech stocks bore the brunt of Friday's selloff as investors pulled back from the overheated sector. U.S. stocks fell Friday after President Trump said he and the first lady tested positive for coronavirus, but all three major indexes held on to notch gains for the week.

title: It's No Surprise When Someone Gets Covid
summary: The disease is endemic. And even 74-year-olds can have mild cases that aren't debilitating.. Not quite nobody expected this latest twist in our year of living derangedly. On waking to the news that shook markets and discombobulated our politics Friday morning, I thought back to an email, typically flippant, I sent colleagues a few weeks ago: "Biden secret plan: let Trump be the candidate who gets Covid . . . an October surprise I wouldn't bet against."

title: Turkey's Covid-19 Figures Questioned After Asymptomatic Cases Omitted
summary: Doctors criticize government's admission that statistics count only patients with symptoms; U.K. imposes quarantine on travelers from Turkey. ISTANBUL-The severity of Turkey's coronavirus outbreak was called into question after the government acknowledged it wasn't counting asymptomatic cases, triggering criticism from local medical professionals and prompting the U.K. on Friday to toughen quarantine requirements for travelers coming from the country.

title: Supreme Court to Review Arizona Voting Rules
summary: Justices to consider state ban on third-party ballot collection, out-of-precinct voting. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to consider the legality of voting rules in Arizona that prohibit third parties from delivering early-voting ballots and disallow in-person ballots that are submitted in the wrong precinct.

title: Pelosi Signals Support for Airline Aid as Relief Talks Continue
summary: House Speaker calls on carriers to delay job cuts as Congress crafts legislation. WASHINGTON-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Friday she is willing to move forward with aid for airlines as separate legislation or as part of a broader coronavirus relief deal that Democrats and the White House continue to negotiate as carriers prepare to cut thousands of jobs.

title: U.S., EU Sanction Belarus in Coordinated Western Action
summary: Lukashenko government lashes out, saying no 'self-respecting' state would agree to demands posed by the West. The U.S. and European Union imposed sanctions against Belarus officials on Friday, part of a coordinated effort by Western allies to censure the authoritarian regime over accusations of political repression and rigging elections.

title: Harvey Weinstein Faces New Rape Charges in California
summary: Los Angeles district attorney's office announces six additional counts of sex assault. Los Angeles prosecutors charged Harvey Weinstein, the once-internationally acclaimed Hollywood producer, with six additional sexual assault counts on Friday.

title: After Record U.S. Corporate-Bond Sales, Slowdown Expected
summary: Blockbuster issuance could fade as refinancings ebb and companies cut debt. U.S. companies sold more debt during the third quarter of 2020 than ever before, extending this year's record-breaking bond bonanza into the second half of the year even as some analysts predict a slowdown.

title: Academy Sports Tests Investor Appetite for Retail
summary: Shares of KKR-owned sporting-goods chain decline in market debut even after cutting its offering price. Shares of Academy Sports & Outdoors Inc. fell in their market debut Friday, even after the company lowered its asking price, highlighting the challenge the sporting-goods chain faces in winning over investors when much of the retail sector is ailing.

title: The Trumps vs. Covid-19
summary: A speedy recovery would not just help the first family.. White House chief of staff Mark Meadows says President Donald Trump is in good spirits and continuing to work despite a coronavirus infection. The President shared the news last night on Twitter about himself and First Lady Melania Trump:

title: Democrats and Amy Coney Barrett's Religion
summary: Peggy Noonan doesn't want to see Democrats bashing Judge Amy Coney Barrett, for being an extremist because of her Catholic faith.. Peggy Noonan isn't in favor of Republicans considering a conservative to fill the seat of a liberal icon on the Supreme Court before the election, but she also doesn't want to see Democrats bashing President Trump's nominee, Judge Amy Coney Barrett, for being an extremist because of her Catholic faith ("The Truth About People of Praise," Declarations, Sept. 26).

title: Newsom's Coup Against Gas-Powered Cars
summary: Gov. Newsom is saying: "If you like your gas-powered car, you can keep your gas-powered car.". I generally have respect for Gov. Gavin Newsom but your criticism of the governor's coming gas-powered car ban in "California's Electric Autopia," Review and Outlook, Sept. 26) only scratches the surface. Even in his "climate damn emergency" speech that was so widely covered and set the stage for this order, the governor acknowledged the reality of forest management in reducing the intensity of fires in California. Yet he decides to make international headlines with a "bold" car ban that will neither be accountable on his watch, nor stop communities from burning next year and, worst of all, will do almost nothing to stop global warming given California's small carbon footprint globally. Why not instead introduce a bold, immediately actionable plan to do the one thing that California does have control over-manage its own lands?

title: Enough of Zoom-Office Happy Hours Return
summary: After months of virtual meetings, some employees are finding ways to get back to in-person socials and the connections they had missed. They made do for a while with Zoom happy hours. But as coronavirus cases eased, office workers at KDG, a professional technology services company in Allentown, Pa., were eager to get together for drinks in person.

title: Vote-Harvesting Ban Would Raise Election Confidence
summary: There is scarcely any limit to the damage that can be done by gathering and sorting ballots (mail-in or absentee), hidden from public view.. William Galston is right to criticize President Trump's blathering generalities about mail-in voting, such as "get rid of the ballots" ("Make America Trust Elections Again," Politics & Ideas, Sept. 30). But he commits an egregious error of omission by failing to mention the grave danger of "ballot harvesting." There is scarcely any limit to the damage that can be done by gathering and sorting ballots (mail-in or absentee), hidden from public view, and only delivering those favorable to one's preferred candidate. Such chicanery has already forced a redo of the 2018 North Carolina Ninth Congressional District election-an option that will not be available in November's presidential contest. By consistently avoiding consideration of the proven dangers of well-funded and well-organized ballot-harvesting campaigns, commentators such as Mr. Galston, and activist judges, do voters a grave disservice.

title: So Much for John Kerry's Views on Syria's Civil War
summary: During the depths of the Syrian war, John Kerry declared that there was no military solution to the conflict, only a political resolution.. Michael Oren's "Triumph for Peace is a Humiliation for the Peace Industry" (op-ed, Sept. 24) raises trenchant questions about John Kerry's concept of "hard reality" to achieve Middle East peace. During the depths of the Syrian war, the former secretary of state declared that there was no military solution to the conflict, only a political resolution. Really? The Russian air force, pro-Iranian ground troops and Hezbollah fighters demonstrated his fatally flawed misunderstanding of this region.

title: Justice Department Appeals Injunction Against WeChat App
summary: Trump administration ordered ban against the app, saying it poses a national-security risk because data could be shared with China's government. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration filed court papers Friday seeking to overturn a federal magistrate's Sept. 20 ruling that stopped a U.S. ban on China's ubiquitous messaging and e-commerce app WeChat .

title: Trump and His Aides Have Long Played Down Importance of Face Masks, Distancing
summary: Right up until the hours before the president tested positive for coronavirus, he and his staff often dismissed or ignored public-health safety precautions. WASHINGTON-As he crisscrossed the country campaigning for re-election, President Trump has questioned the effectiveness of wearing face masks and dismissed the risk of holding large campaign rallies, contradicting health experts and the recommendations of his coronavirus task force.

title: Bring Your Dog on Any Fall Adventure-From Hiking to a Hotel Stay
summary: In lockdown, we grew even closer to our dogs. Now, equipped with the right gear and training, they can tag along as we explore the outdoors again, or even just visit a country inn.. WHILE WANDERING the Dutchess County Fair in Rhinebeck, N.Y., in the summer of 2019, I came upon a raucous crowd of people. My wife and 8-year-old daughter in tow, I shouldered my way through to the front, half-expecting to find a bare-knuckle boxing match. Instead, the big reveal was a German shepherd sitting patiently on a long platform at one end of a waist-high oval pool. Athletic, regal, focused and, in an instant, gone. On command, he bolted across the deck, leapt off and soared after a toy his trainer had tossed. When the splash settled, we saw that the canine, a star in what turned out to be a DockDogs competition, had cleared a good 25 feet.

title: Groups Sue Texas Governor Over Ballot Drop-Off Cuts
summary: Greg Abbott said the order is needed to ensure election security. AUSTIN, Texas-Civil-rights and voter-advocacy groups have filed a federal lawsuit seeking to block an order by Texas Gov. Greg Abbott that dramatically reduced the number of drop-off locations for mail ballots.

title: Warehouse, Parcel Operators Add Thousands of Jobs Ahead of Holidays
summary: Companies focused on online commerce already are boosting payrolls while planning to bring in more seasonal workers this year. Companies are adding tens of thousands of warehousing jobs as they scale up e-commerce fulfillment and distribution capacity ahead of a high stakes fourth quarter.

title: Matisse's Radical Harmonies
summary: A new exhibition in Paris explores the painter's creative breakthroughs, with help from the writers who analyzed them. Henri Matisse is often bracketed with Pablo Picasso as the most daringly creative artist of the 20th century. But while Picasso preferred to cloak his art in mystery, Matisse was a theorist and teacher who felt honor-bound to explain his artistic innovations. In his essay "Notes of a Painter," published in 1908, he offered the kind of unpretentious advice that could appeal to any artist starting out: "Composition is the art of arranging in a decorative manner the diverse elements at the painter's command to express his feelings."

title: Job Gains Slow as More Layoffs Become Permanent
summary: Economy added 661,000 jobs in September; unemployment rate fell to 7.9%. Hiring gains slowed sharply heading into the fall as more layoffs turned permanent, adding to signs that the U.S. economy faces a long slog to fully recover from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Coronavirus Delivers an October Surprise
summary: After a disastrous debate and a shocking twist, the vice-presidential debate takes on huge importance.. When the coronavirus epidemic came to the U.S. in February, I thought it would hit the Washington political class hard. Its members spend all their time touching each other-handshakes, back pats. They don't like masks; they think they look goofy and sinister. They'd spread it among each other quickly. As time passed, that appeared not to be true: American politicians didn't seem to have a higher sickness rate than anyone else. Now, in what looks like a formal unveiling of the much-feared second wave-the one scientists spent the summer warning would begin around October-the president, the first lady and the president's closest aide have been infected.

title: The Poetry of the Prosaic
summary: William Carlos Williams's 'The Red Wheelbarrow' offers an intimately human experience in its consideration of a quotidian scene..

title: The U.S. Jobs Recovery Is Sputtering
summary: The latest employment report still leaves the nation's jobs count 10.7 million below where it was in February, before the pandemic hit. In normal times, a monthly employment report that showed the U.S. economy adding 661,000 jobs would be fantastic news. These aren't normal times, though. If anything, the September employment figures counted as bad.

title: Turkey's Foray Into Armenia-Azerbaijan Conflict Tests Russia's Influence
summary: Moscow's attempts to stay neutral over the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict are threatened by President Erdogan's support for Azerbaijan. Turkey's role in the growing clash between Armenia and Azerbaijan-two countries Moscow regards as within its sphere of influence-is adding a new element to a string of proxy fights pitting Turkey and Russia against each other and challenging Russia's longstanding policy of neutrality over the simmering conflict.

title: Walmart's Brexit Goes Smoothly
summary: Now is as good a time as any for Walmart to get out of the U.K. business. Walmart 's long-desired exit from U.K. supermarket business Asda Group finally seems to be within reach. The deal on the table seems to be favorable for both Walmart and Asda.

title: The NFL Scrambles to Close Holes in Covid Defense After Titans Outbreak
summary: The league adopted new measures for teams that may be experiencing an outbreak amid 13 members of the Tennessee Titans organization testing positive since Tuesday. The NFL is undergoing the first outbreak of its pandemic season. Now it's changing its protocols for how to handle outbreaks.

title: Presidential Campaign Moves Deeper Into Unknown Territory
summary: The difference between a mild case and a severe one could have an enormous impact on the race. A presidential campaign that never was on a traditional or predictable course now is in completely uncharted waters.

title: France's Macron Targets 'Islamist Separatism' With Proposed Law
summary: Bill would enable government to shut down organizations and schools seen as supporting radical Islam. PARIS-French President Emmanuel Macron took aim at radical Islam Friday, announcing plans to outlaw what he called "Islamist separatism" in communities where he said religious laws are taking precedence over civil ones.

title: The Serious Silliness of Mo Willems
summary: The creator of 'Don't Let the Pigeon Drive the Bus,' the 'Elephant and Piggie' series and other children's books aspires to explore 'eternal questions' like the meaning of love and disappointment. In a world of children's books overrun with puppies, bunnies and cuddly bears, Mo Willems thought there was room for a pigeon. Not just any pigeon, but a scheming, willful and somewhat embittered bird who rarely gets what he wants.

title: Decaying Yemen Oil Tanker at Risk of Spilling Into Red Sea
summary: Resume Subscription. A rusting oil-storage vessel moored off Yemen's Red Sea coast could rupture or explode, Western officials said Friday, warning of an environmental and humanitarian catastrophe if it breaks apart.

title: Long-Term Unemployment Poses Rising Risk to the Economy
summary: Workers who haven't been called back to their jobs face the prospect of prolonged joblessness and income loss. More workers identified themselves as permanently laid off and unemployed for the long term in September, a sign the labor market's recovery from the coronavirus pandemic is likely to be slow and protracted.

title: Allbirds' Dual-CEO Arrangement Is a Rare Specimen
summary: Double-occupancy corner offices can feel crowded, but when they work, two heads are better than one. Shortly after I emailed San Francisco-based Allbirds Inc. in June to talk about its new running shoe, the Tree Dasher, Chief Executive Tim Brown got on the phone to discuss how an eco-friendly company known for comfy-casual kicks will approach a more discerning segment of the market.

title: Trump's Positive Covid Test Is Another Reason for Investors to Look Away
summary: The election is getting more uncertain every day, but investors should avoid getting carried away. It would be difficult to imagine a U.S. election subject to more uncertainty than this year's. The less investors bank on specific outcomes the better.

title: Richard Branson's Virgin Turns to SPAC to Raise Cash
summary: British billionaire plans to expand at a time when his core businesses have been hit hard by Covid-19. Richard Branson's Virgin Group has floated a special-purpose acquisition company in New York, raising $480 million to expand an empire that has been hobbled by the pandemic, and joining a parade of offerings known as blank-check listings.

title: The World That War Has Made
summary: Armed conflict has long meant tragedy but has also contributed to the emergence of everything from penicillin and highways to universal suffrage and the welfare state. Let us start, as many do every morning, with a croissant. Yet how many of us know about that familiar pastry's association with one of history's pivotal military victories? In 1683, when Habsburg forces outside Vienna defeated an invading Ottoman army, Viennese bakers were said to have celebrated by baking crescents, the symbol of the departing Muslim forces. If that battle had turned out differently, the Ottomans might have dominated the heart of Europe for the next centuries, and the region's inhabitants would have become largely Muslim. Or consider some more recent examples: Imagine if the Axis powers, not the Allies, had won World War II-or the Soviet Union the Cold War.

title: World Leaders Who Have Had Covid-19
summary: A number of world leaders have contracted the coronavirus since the start of the pandemic. Here's a rundown.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: 'Silences So Deep' Review: Northern Symphony
summary: Inspired by 'Walden,' a composer made the wilderness his muse.. John Luther Adams spent much of his adult life in Alaska, not for the mountains or the stargazing but for the quiet. It allowed the composer to think, and, more important, to listen. He carried a music notebook on walks and took dictation directly from the birds. He practiced his tympani parts for the Fairbanks Symphony Orchestra on sofa pillows. In the backcountry cabin where he lived alone for most of the 1980s, he had one clock and resented its every tick. So he kept it in the refrigerator where he could not hear it. "If I really needed to know the time," he writes in his new memoir, "I had to make a conscious decision to walk into the kitchen area, open the door, and peer in among the fruits and vegetables."

title: 'Wild Thing' Review: Out of This World
summary: With a career cut tragically short, Jimi Hendrix's guitar magic set listeners-and musicians-reeling.. Flush with a giddiness and bafflement that few will ever know, the young musician who seems to have vaulted from obscurity to stardom overnight finds himself on the cusp of a new life, one that promises pleasure and the kind of wealth that would have made him the envy of ancient monarchs. Yet there is peril, too, and mystery. Before, he struggled for work, love, even food. Now everyone adores him or claims to, like the worldly woman sitting across from him in a New York apartment who, having met him a few hours earlier, asks if he'd like some acid. "No thanks," says Jimi Hendrix, "but I'd like to try some of that LSD stuff." He would try it again and again along with every other drug in the rock pharmacopeia, but his first trip was portentous in an especially eerie way: When he looked into a mirror, he saw not his own face but Marilyn Monroe's.

title: 'Goya: A Portrait of the Artist' Review: Dreams & Nightmares
summary: Haunted by human cruelty and folly, the painter's work still bewitches.. Nearly 20 years ago, Robert Hughes reflected on the head-on car accident that almost killed him: "It was through the accident that I came to know extreme pain, fear, and despair," he wrote in the introduction of his biography of Francisco Goya y Lucientes, "and it may be that the writer who does not know fear, despair, and pain cannot fully know Goya." I will henceforth rationalize the last nine months as elaborate preparation for Janis Tomlinson's new "Portrait" of the artist.

title: 'The Discomfort of Evening' Review: Child of Sin
summary: A tale of religious dread and worse unfolds on an isolated Dutch farm.. 'The Discomfort of Evening," the first novel by the poet Marieke Lucas Rijneveld, is a sensation in every sense of the word. The first Dutch literary work to win the International Booker Prize (Mx. Rijneveld, who uses the gender-neutral honorific, is also the award's youngest-ever recipient at 29), and by then a subversive bestseller, this childhood narrative of overwhelming grief, religious insanity, death and incest, cruelty and despair, is felt in the gut as much as it is in the heart. Some of its scenes, indeed, are almost unbearable: the mass slaughter of an infected dairy herd, for example, or a sexual assault involving farm equipment. Yet the novel's power resides not in its ability to stun, but rather in the compressed grace of the author's plain style-lucidly conveyed by the translator Michele Hutchison-which conjures up a hermetically sealed reality and an adolescent protagonist so believable and unguarded that from the outset we feel her closeness and fear for her safety. "I was ten and stopped taking off my coat," she begins and with that simple declaration lures us into a tale vibrating with tension and saturated with dread.

title: Five Best: John Banville on 'Big House' Books
summary: From the author of the novel 'Snow.'. By Maria Edgeworth (1800)

title: Science Fiction: First Impressions
summary: Christopher Paolini goes from fantasy to faster-than-light travel.. Who would have thought it? Space opera is back, and on a scale we haven't seen since E.E. "Doc" Smith, or in modern times, Larry Niven and Jerry Pournelle's "Mote in God's Eye" sequence. And written by a guy who does young adult fantasies! Christopher Paolini's "To Sleep in a Sea of Stars" (Tor, 878 pages, $29.99) is what Tolkien called a wish beyond hope.

title: Mysteries: A Yank in the Emerald Isle
summary: Tana French puts a retired American cop on the hunt for a missing Irish boy.. 'I came here to get away from old habits," says the 48-year-old Cal Hooper, a retired veteran of the Chicago Police Department who, in Tana French's novel "The Searcher" (Viking, 451 pages, $27), has moved to a village in West Ireland. But old habits die hard.

title: Children's Books: Strangers in a New Land
summary: A poignant memoir of a child's journey from Iran to the U.S. finds healing in connection.. 'If we can just rise to the challenge of communication-here in the parlor of your mind-we can maybe reach across time and space and every ordinary thing to see so deep into the heart of each other that you might agree that I am like you." Thus does Daniel Nayeri invite us to join what he calls a "complicated conversation" in "Everything Sad Is Untrue" (Levine Querido, 356 pages, $17.99), his brilliant memoir of dislocated boyhood.

title: Toy Marketer Roger Shiffman Unleashed Furby and Giga Pets
summary: 'Grown-up kid' relied on his instincts and ability to outmaneuver industry giants. Roger Shiffman was perfectly cast as the public face of a toy company, Tiger Electronics Inc., maker of Furby, Giga Pets and other hits of the 1980s and 1990s. He had a jungle of curly brown hair and a cherubic expression that prompted the Chicago Tribune to describe him as a grown-up kid.

title: Edie Locke, Refugee From Nazis, Edited Mademoiselle Magazine
summary: Editor upheld highbrow traditions and lost job after refusing to mimic Cosmopolitan. The teenage Edie Laub, growing up in Vienna, knew about anti-Semitism. Still, when Nazi troops occupied Austria in March 1938, she was stunned by the reaction of schoolmates she considered friends. "Open the windows," one shrieked. "It stinks of Jews."

title: Arthur Ashkin Used Lasers to Trap Atoms and Cells
summary: Bell Labs physicist won 2018 Nobel Prize for optical tweezers, used in medical research. As a scientist at Bell Laboratories in Holmdel, N.J., Arthur Ashkin sometimes felt inadequate.

title: Covid-19 Vaccines Should First Go to Health Workers, First Responders, Panel Says
summary: U.S. government needs to direct limited initial coronavirus vaccines to those at the front lines of treatment and high-risk groups, panel says. Certain health workers and first responders should be the first to receive a Covid-19 vaccine when one becomes available, followed by people with health conditions that put them at higher risk of severe Covid-19 disease, a special U.S. committee recommended.

title: Wilshire Associates Agrees to Sale
summary: CC Capital and Motive Partners to acquire pension data and advisory firm. Two private-equity firms agreed to acquire Wilshire Associates, a 48-year-old employee-owned investment advisory, management and data firm.

title: How to Avoid the 5 Worst Kitchen Design Mistakes
summary: We asked architects and designers how to steer clear of cabinet chaos and kitchen-island excesses. Plus: The silliest flubs our pros have ever seen.. ALL-WHITE kitchens that look like operating theaters aren't all that inspiring or even practical. But the overcooked alternatives-kitchens featuring grease-accumulating ceramic roosters or cabinetry festooned with grape-leaf swags-can seem depressingly cluttered. "It's a place for creating meals, not Versailles," said New York architect Kevin Lichten.

title: 'Anarchy' Is Not a New York City Crisis. It's a Lifestyle.
summary: Critics who bemoan a 'decline' don't get it-this town happily embraces its chaos. My fellow anarchists of New York City:

title: Tesla, Amazon.com, Uber, Twilio: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: The Dow is on track to drop over 450 points at the open. Oil prices also fell sharply after President Trump and the first lady tested positive for the coronavirus. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Friday.

title: The Year the Entire WNBA Became Political Players
summary: The women's basketball league has long included activism. In 2020, it built a season on it.. Years before the NFL painted "End Racism" in its end zones, before NBA players emblazoned their jerseys with social-justice messages endorsed by the league, WNBA players were demonstrating for change-and getting in trouble for it.

title: Merck's R&D Chief to Retire
summary: Roger Perlmutter steered Merck toward developing cancer immunotherapy, which helped reshape the company's fortunes. Merck & Co. R & D chief Roger Perlmutter, who turned around the drugmaker's labs by embracing cancer immunotherapy, will retire at the end of the year, the company said.

title: QAnon Lands on LinkedIn, Prompting Networking Site to Limit Spread
summary: As more users show support for the conspiracy theories, the website reacts to those who break its guidelines. Supporters of QAnon are increasingly going public on LinkedIn, expanding their online presence and prompting the professional-networking site to take steps to limit the spread of the community that promotes politically themed conspiracy theories.

title: John Slattery on Playing a Tech Billionaire Who's Losing His Mind
summary: "Is he crazy, or is it just that the story he's trying to tell people sounds crazy?". Actor John Slattery says that the creators of the new show he stars in, NEXT on Fox, wanted to make a science-fiction show without the science fiction. Slattery, 58, plays Paul LeBlanc, the founder of a tech company that creates an artificial intelligence, which he is the first to recognize is dangerous. But don't expect armies of killer robots. "The low-concept elements to how artificial intelligence can operate are more interesting," says the actor during an old-fashioned phone interview. The show explores scenarios like what happens when AI gets into an Alexa-like speaker in one of the character's homes, for example.

title: The Hidden Risk in Detroit's Big Bet on Trucks
summary: Demand for expensive pickups and sport-utility vehicles has yet to be affected by the pandemic. The U.S. car industry needs it to stay that way.. Could leaner times interest Americans in leaner vehicles? There's no sign yet, but any recessionary shift back to cars would show up the pitfalls of Detroit's all-out bet on trucks.

title: Walmart Sells Majority Stake in Asda to U.K. Consortium in $8.8 Billion Deal
summary: Deal comes after antitrust regulators blocked Walmart's previous effort to sell the business to U.K.'s Sainsbury. Walmart Inc. agreed to sell its U.K. grocery-store chain Asda Group Ltd. to a private investment group in a deal that values the company at 6.8 billion pounds, equivalent to $8.8 billion, as the world's largest retailer reorganizes its international businesses in favor of bets on the growth of online services.

title: Today's Logistics Report: Buying Into Uber Freight; Maritime's Fresh Cyberattacks; Moving Boeing Planes
summary: Today's Top Supply Chain & Logistics News. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: Some Police Chiefs Rush Out Video of Shootings
summary: While departments say they offer evidence to rebut false narratives, accountability advocates warn practice could be self-serving. With tensions running high across the country over instances of police violence, Detroit Police Chief James Craig went in front of TV cameras about an hour after a police shooting in July, explaining that the suspect had pulled a gun and fired at an officer before police killed him.

title: The Pandemic Erased a Year of Booing the Astros. Now They're Surging.
summary: Houston has largely escaped the jeers as fans were unable to express their outrage over the team's sign-stealing scandal this season. The most notorious cheaters in modern baseball history spent 2020 earning another title that only further cemented them as the most hated team in all of American professional sports: the ultimate escape artists.

title: Never Forget Your Face Mask With These Home Design Tips
summary: Decorating tricks to organize and outfit your entryway with style-and make safety a no-brainer. IT IS TIME for an entryway intervention. These formerly warm, welcoming spaces have turned into mini medical-supply stores-dumping grounds for masks, rubber gloves, bottles of hand sanitizer and wipes galore. With space at a premium, safety-minded tastemakers are struggling to add personal protective equipment to an existing mix of coats, shoes and backpacks in an orderly yet stylish way.

title: Uber Postmates Combo Could Be a Raw Deal
summary: Newly released financial details suggest Postmates might not turn out to be as tasty as Uber had hoped. It seems Uber Technologies may have been hungrier than investors appreciated.

title: Banks Can Only Tighten Their Belts So Much
summary: For investors, revelations about banks and money laundering highlight just how hard it will be for banks to improve returns if both revenues and costs are under pressure. The recent revelation of financial suspicious activity reports, known as the FinCEN Files, has sparked a flurry of discussion about banks' role in money laundering. From a bank investor's point of view, though, the controversy may mainly serve as a reminder that banks have a built-in cost base that isn't going anywhere.

title: Canadian Pensions Find Opportunity in Private Debt
summary: Retirement systems hope private loans will bring better returns in a low-yield environment.

title: Instagram Turns 10: How the App Helped Democratize Art
summary: For many creators trying to find an audience, Instagram-turning 10 this month-was a place to find confidence and level the playing field. ON OCT. 6, 2010, 25,000 people signed up for a new photo app dubbed Instagram. Within a week, that figure flew past 100,000 and now the number of active users tops out at more than 1 billion. In its decade of memes and latte photos, Insta Stories and double taps, the platform's most notable contribution to humankind is arguably access. Users can come in contact with places, things and anyone with a phone worldwide, often in real time.

title: Athletes Are Conquering Distance. Sports Will Never Be the Same.
summary: Basketball stars are shooting from deeper, golfers are driving farther and marathoners are running faster. Today's athletes are breaking their games.. For a couple of hours between the NBA and WNBA Finals, the Major League Baseball playoffs, French Open matches and NFL action this weekend, the fastest human in history will walk into a park and run circles for 26.2 miles.

title: Walmart Doesn't Need TikTok to Get Excited
summary: Early surveys indicate healthy number of online shoppers are willing to try retailer's new subscription service. Walmart shares have been on a roller-coaster ride since reports began coming out of the retailer's stake in a potential TikTok deal. Lost in the whirlwind has been something more tangible that is worth getting excited about: Walmart+, the retailer's new subscription service.

title: Uber Sells Stake in Freight Unit to Private Investors
summary: A $500 million funding round from a group led by Greenbriar Equity brings in cash as the ride-hailing parent copes with faltering core business.

title: President and First Lady Melania Test Positive for the Coronavirus
summary: President's infection means he will need to cancel in-person events in the coming weeks. WASHINGTON-President Trump and first lady Melania Trump tested positive for Covid-19, injecting fresh uncertainty into an already tumultuous final stretch of the 2020 campaign.

title: Online Platforms Ask Users to Be Polite With 'Nudges'
summary: LinkedIn is the latest social network to see whether it can encourage more civil conversation. Can people really be deterred from posting hateful messages online just by asking them not to?

title: New Covid-19 Cases Start to Fall in Hard-Hit Latin America
summary: Resume Subscription. SÃO PAULO-The Covid-19 pandemic has ravaged Latin America, killing more than 300,000 people, erasing years of social and economic gains and plunging millions back into poverty. But from Mexico to Brazil, a recent slowdown in new cases and fatalities is raising cautious hopes that the hard-hit region might be turning a corner.

title: Companies Tap Inside Talent to Steer Finances Through the Pandemic
summary: Ford, Jones Lang LaSalle, Altria and Occidental in recent months promoted from within to fill a CFO vacancy. Companies, especially in hard-hit industries, are turning to familiar faces to help them steer their finances through the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Dallas Agency Brings Coding In-House to Target Covid-19 Aid
summary: Dallas Housing Authority staff rejiggered sales software to help distribute Cares Act rental assistance faster and more equitably. The Dallas Housing Authority's efforts to distribute Covid-19 housing assistance to the city's renters were bolstered by a sales software system reconfigured with features that enabled officials to grant aid more quickly and equitably.

title: What to Do if Student Loans Make Getting a Mortgage Hard
summary: Don't despair. There are steps to take that could help you qualify for a loan.. Despite the coronavirus lockdowns, or helped by them perhaps, much of the U.S. is in the midst of a red-hot housing market. But buying a home can be challenging if you have student debt.

title: Shale Companies Had Lousy Returns. Their CEOs Got Paid Anyway.
summary: Some of the biggest raises in corporate America went to the executives in charge of U.S. shale companies, even as their shareholders lost billions of dollars. It's been a bad few years for investors in shale companies, but a pretty good few years for shale company CEOs.

title: Tokyo Stock Exchange Resumes Trading After Daylong Shutdown
summary: Malfunctioning disk device is blamed for unprecedented full-day trading halt. TOKYO-The Tokyo Stock Exchange resumed normal trading Friday after an unprecedented all-day shutdown Thursday that executives blamed on a malfunctioning computer part.

title: A Major Miner's Daunting Dig Could Reshape the Iron-Ore Market
summary: Rio Tinto's next CEO faces a decision on a costly but coveted African project that 'represents a major threat to long-term iron-ore prices'. SYDNEY- Rio Tinto PLC's next leader will inherit a decision that could define the miner's next decade: whether to partner with China on a potentially lucrative but costly African project that could reshape the iron-ore market.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: How Covid Broke Times Square, the Heart of New York's Economy
summary: The neighborhood is feeling the full force of the downturn in real estate, Broadway, tourism and retail; 'All of a sudden everything is toxic'. NEW YORK-A young man walked into a jewelry store near Times Square in July and asked to see the shop's most expensive earrings. Then he grabbed them and ran off.

title: New Migrant Caravan From Honduras Heads Toward U.S. Border
summary: Caravan could provide ammunition to President Trump's re-election campaign, but experts say it will likely be broken up. MEXICO CITY-A group of about 3,000 Honduran migrants, including many women and children, overwhelmed soldiers and police as they crossed into Guatemala on Thursday, heading toward the U.S. southern border to flee poverty and rising joblessness brought by the pandemic.

title: Judge Partially Blocks Trump Administration From Enforcing Visa Ban
summary: Ruling affects workers on H-1B and other types of visas through end of 2020. A federal judge in San Francisco has blocked the Trump administration from enforcing its ban against many of the biggest U.S. companies bringing in foreign workers under H-1B and other employment-based visas.

title: Moody's Downgrades New York State, New York City Credit Ratings
summary: Ratings concern cites mounting toll of coronavirus pandemic on state and local economies, with sales-tax and income-tax revenues cratering. Moody's Investors Service downgraded the credit ratings of both New York City and New York state on Thursday, a consequence of the coronavirus pandemic's mounting toll on the New York economy.

title: In Win for Mexican Leader, Top Court Approves Referendum on Former Presidents
summary: A number of Mexican lawyers dismissed the proposed referendum as an unconstitutional exercise. MEXICO CITY-Mexico's Supreme Court approved Thursday a plan by President Andrés Manuel López Obrador to hold a referendum on whether five former presidents should be investigated and possibly prosecuted for corruption.

title: George Melloan, Wall Street Journal Commentator, Dies at Age 92
summary: Indiana-born journalist was foreign correspondent, columnist and deputy to Robert L. Bartley. George Melloan, who retired in 2006 after a 54-year career at The Wall Street Journal and was part of a team of editorial-page writers who advocated lower taxes and reduced government regulation, died earlier this week, his family said Thursday. He was 92.

title: Trian Takes Stakes in Invesco, Janus Henderson With Eye on Deals
summary: Money comes in part from a fund built with the goal of bringing consolidation to the asset-management industry. Shareholder activist Trian Fund Management LP has taken big stakes in investment firms Invesco Ltd. and Janus Henderson Group PLC and plans to agitate for deal making aimed at building a rival to the biggest asset managers in the world.

title: House Passes $2.2 Trillion Coronavirus Relief Bill in Absence of Bipartisan Deal
summary: Republicans have panned the Democratic bill, giving it no chance of passage in the GOP-controlled Senate. WASHINGTON-The House passed a $2.2 trillion coronavirus relief bill Thursday as bipartisan negotiations with the Trump administration dragged on, with Democrats moving forward on their legislation in the absence of a deal with Republicans.

title: Amazon Says More Than 19,000 Workers Have Had Positive Coronavirus Tests
summary: The biggest company to disclose such data says the number of positive cases is below what it expected. Amazon.com Inc. on Thursday said more than 19,000 of its workers have tested positive for the novel coronavirus, the first time so major a U.S. employer has disclosed such data.
